data.title: Use the battlefield news query to send system stats to the master server
data.body:
Before we can fix #10661 we need an idea of how many players this will affect.
The battlefield news query runs once per game start, so it gives us a simple way to track active player statistics (unless the player explicitly opts out).

Implementation:
1. Add a `http://master.openra.net/gamenews` page, which can initially just do a http redirect to http://openra.net/gamenews.
2.  Change the `NewsUrl` to this new value.
3. Add an advanced setting for sending system statistics (enabled by default).
4. If the setting is enabled, send the current mod, `Platform.CurrentPlatform`, `Environment.OSVersion`, and `Platform.RuntimeVersion` (these are the same things we include in exception.log) as either GET or POST data along with the news query.
5. (can be left until after release) Change the gamenews page to start logging this information so that we look at aggregate OS/usage stats.

If we want to do anything about #10661 in the next year we really need to get this logging in the next release, so adding to the milestone.

data.title: Drop Windows XP and .NET 4.0 support.
data.body:
Maintaining Windows XP support means that we are stuck with .NET 4.0, which is holding us back in a number of ways (which I expect to grow as time goes on):
1.  We can't fix our broken UPNP support because OpenNAT has only ever supported .NET >= 4.5 (#7140).  This then leads to confusion from people who don't know why we have a port forwarding option that can't obviously be enabled.
2.  The GeoIP library has recently dropped support for .NET < 4.5, so we are now stuck on an older version that won't receive bugfixes and makes life more difficult for linux packagers (#10280).
3.  The Roslyn compiler will give us access to much more powerful analysis tools for linting and documentation generation, but can only target the .NET >= 4.5 runtimes.
4.  Xamarin now only maintain partial support the 4.0 runtime by shipping pre-compiled assemblies (it is no longer possible to compile them from source, AFAIK).   Linux distros such as Fedora and Debian testing will not distribute these, so we can't support OpenRA on these platforms unless the player compiles/installs their own version of mono.
5. Microsoft have dropped all support for .NET 4.0 (https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/lifecycle?C2=548), and Windows > XP support 4.5.2 or greater.

Depends on #10662.  Pulling the rug out from anyone who does use XP isn't very polite, so we need to know how big of an effect this will have.

data.title: Replace Server.LockBots option with Server.DisableSinglePlayer
data.body:
The LockBots option was originally added in response to players using dedicated servers to play 1vbot games (back in the days when only TD had the skirmish mode).  Disabling bots even for proper multiplayer games is overkill, and rather unfair.

This has become topical again with the recent flood of players who have been asking / complaining about port forwarding.  Our best response "You don't need to - we provide dedicated servers for this" falls flat when one of the main game options for casual players is explicitly disallowed on them.

This is easy to fix and gives a big usability win, so i'm suggesting that we prioritise this for the next release. We already have code in place to disable the game starting if specific lobby slots are not full, and this can be extended with an additional check for > 1 human players.

data.title: Improve sync performance
data.body:
Previously, generating the sync hash for each syncable trait required a lookup to find the hash function every tick, as well as lookups for the syncable traits.

Instead, we now cache these lookups on actor creation as they do not change. This means we avoid repeated lookups for the traits and the hash functions.

On the RA shellmap, this reduces time spent syncing the world state from 9.65% of total CPU to 6.88%.

data.title: Random tileset terrain painting
data.body:
A friend of mine [topaxi](https://github.com/topaxi) had the idea to paint cliffs randomly of the same type. I couldn't find any functionality or an issue to something similar, so I've created a prototype function:

https://github.com/Sapena/OpenRA/tree/similar_terrain_tilesets b86ea5a9d0a422c9da83da76a617939f88688155

The idea is to be able to drag a line of cliffs and the editor switches automatically the templates, but only using similar tiles. The prototype for now only works with the vertical and horizontal cliffs (Excluding the diagonal cliffs):
- Horizontal: 135-141, 149-155
- Vertical: 142-148, 156-162

The functionality could be applied to other kind of tiles, like water cliffs, roads, etc. Another extended and nice functionality would be, that the editor is able to handle displacements, like moving upwards while dragging a horizontal line.

Is this idea usable? Or just kind of overkill?

data.title: Implement special-case actor yaml merging.
data.body:
Proposed fix for #10207.  It passes @RoosterDragon's test case (after fixing a couple of errors in the test), and fixes fort lonestar in RA.  More testing is required in all mods: ~~there are side-effects (e.g. the turbocharged hovercraft in TD) which could eithery be a bug in new new parsing or old rules that are being parsed "correctly" for the first time.~~

As I explained in #10207 all these bugs are caused because the code tries to treat yaml merging and inheritance as separable steps, which is bogus.  This implements line-by-line rule parsing that immediately resolves inherits and removals.
